intro: Thlaspi montanum var. fendleri, commonly known as the Sierra Wallflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbage plants. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine environments, preferring well-drained soils and full sun exposure. Its flowers are usually bright yellow or orange, with four petals arranged in a cross shape, a characteristic feature of the Brassicaceae family. The plant has hairy stems and leaves, and it produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds.
